Benton Strives For Laboratory Perfection
By TED ROHRLICH
George Benton appears confident amidst the
uncertainty that comes with fall.
A scientist, he approaches his new job with
laboratory precision.
The new Dean of Arts and Sciences, Benton is a
"pusher"--a man who cherishes a challenge and
says he has an answer.
"I know damn well I can organize this campus,"
asserted the 52-year-old dean. A dominating
presence lends credence to his contention.
"Internal procedures within this administration
are miserable. A lot of times when students thought
they were getting the run around, nothing was done
because the mechanisms didn't exist."
"We've got to change more quickly than most of
the faculty would like to have us change," he said,
"but probably not as quickly as most of the students
would like to have us change."
Centralize Authority
President Gordon tapped Benton for the dean's
post vacated by Allyn Kimball in an attempt to
centralize authority on Homewood campus and
take some local responsibilities off his own
shoulders. Benton took over July 1.
"The President of the University can't be expected to spend 80 percent of his time on Arts and
Sciences (one division) simply because he sits on
this campus historically," contended
Benton.
Reviewing the history of present expectations, he
recalled, the year before President Gordon took
office in 1967 that "all of the top
administrative
talent had left nearly simultaneou
sly."
For years Hopkins needed
to make the transition from a personal kind
of organization to a
more structured organizatio
n, but a couple of
handful of longtime administrat
ors held on. When
they left, there was chaos."
Looking a trifle
uncomfortable amidst the

comfortably modern trappings of his new Gilman
Hall Office, Benton pointed to a complicating
factor--"a deterioration of empathy between
students, faculty and administrators."
Department Power
"To the extent the undergraduate body is
decoupled from the departments (with the advent
of the area major) it is decoupled from the major
academic decisions.
"But Hopkins, because of its size, ought to be able
to meet the changing needs of higher education
better than any other university in the country.
"That is something for the whole university
community to consider. And, " he cautioned, "it
should not be done too quickly."
There is plenty of room for advice in the process,
he added.
"An advisory role here could be either difficult or
effective," he observed. "It depends on how
seriously it is taken.

"The Student Affairs Committee labored long to
be responsible last year and came in with what it
believed to be responsible recommendations, but it
was reporting at the wrong place (the Director of
Student Affairs) and suffering from a lack of information."
"It's up to me to make sure they get the information they need."
Chin resting on folded hands, he concluded, "We
need a simpler organization, so we don't wind up
bucking everything to the President."
"I have a rather peculiar combination of experiences which I think you'd find hard to match in
the present faculty," he said.
Background
Benton came to Hopkins in 1948 after a brief stint
at the University of Chicago. His field is
meteorology.
Active in governance as chairman of three
departments and a member of the faculty governing body in the pre-1966 School of Engineering,
Benton got a "substantial dose of administration"
he recalled, when he headed up the research
laboratories of the Federal Environmental Science
Services Administration from 1966 to 1969.
He became the focus of widespread attention here
last spring when, as dean-designate, he stepped to
the fore during the administration's negotiations
with the Strike Committee.
"My first instinct was to stay out of it," he
recalled. "Then I thought things were becoming
more tense. I couldn't afford to stay out of it."
But Benton said he is anxious to pass over the
events of last spring.
"My role then was blocking back, not quarterback."
"Responsibility without authority is not for me,"
he asserted.
As Dean, he'll have plenty of both.

Women As Salvation
By HENRY SUSSMAN
This is simply to welcome you, undergraduate women, to Hopkins, to point out
some of the reasons why your belated
presence is perhaps the most important
development ever to take place here, and to
encourage you to join together and actively
implei-nent the necessary environmental
changes that would be impossible without
you.
The predominant spirit motivating this
community becomes apparent in the form of
its architecture. Phallic Gilman Hall, with
its implicit assertions of power and
opulence, rules the setting. Hidden from
sight, and underground, in the passages of
the vagina-like Milton S. Eisenhower
Library, the aspirants pursue these values.
The degree of submissiveness complements the level of aspiration; the
exaggeration of the goals equals the depth to
which we de-elevate in order to attain them.
Hopkins, a fitting reflection of the dreary
Baltimore environment, when as a fine
university, it could generate a vibrant
alternative — is dominated by the
puritanism of its goals, and by the ease with
which it accedes to the prevalent power
structures outside the University.
It is the same capitalism to which so many
members of this community capitulate
personally, and which the University as a
whole fosters, that motivates the American
economy to repress the potential of most of
its citizens, and notably its women.
Waste of Potential
The same waste of potential is manifested
in the fact that the 2000 undergraduate
males, during the most potent years of
youth, experience the possibility of monastic
sexual repression, or of coming to regard
women as weekend plastic Jesuses, simply
because they elected this academic community.
Sexism, and the repressions which it encourages, perhaps plays a part in the other
instances of waste conspicuous at Hopkins:
* the poverty, in the formal curriculum, of
offerings in the Humanities, and especially
in the Social Sciences;
- * the absence both of instruction and activity in the performing arts (Writing
Seminars is the happy exception);
* the inability of any sustained political
movement to realize its ends, whether
finally to abolish the Applied Physics
Laboratory and ROTC, or to convince the
community that their presence is justified;
* the failure of the University to actively
extend its educational offices to blacks and

underpriveleged whites who, with the aid of
Upward Bound and transitional year
programs, would be able to appreciate the
full range of resources at Hopkins (and at
Hopkins alone in this region);
* and, the less concrete but nonetheless
significant sense that because the campus is
so decentralized, and because function,so
much supercedes person in the prevailing
values, community is impossible.
Admirable Aspect
It is not the most debasing, but the most
admirable aspect of femaleness that can
inspire a richer cultural awareness in the
Hopkins community, increased sensitivity to
the political implications of the universi.tY,
ana tne desire at its members to live
together as brothers and sisters.
Your physical presence alone has an intangible, but formidable effect in
humanizing the atmosphere. More definite
changes will require concerted political and
cultural activity, among yourselves, and
together with the groups that have already
formed in order to effect necessary reforms.
Although it caters to the scions of the
upper classes, in its political, social, and
psycho-sexual dimensions, Hopkins remains
an underpriveleged area.
The wholehearted pursuit of any of the
activities that at more normal campuses
enrich the tone of living--music, theater,
dance, helping in the community at large-takes on, in the stultifying atmosphere that
has evolved here, near-revolutionary consequence.
Vestiges of Sexism
It is likely that you will experience, in
formal and spontaneous behaviors, vestiges
of the sexism that has prevailed in this
University for so many years.
But sexism, like militarism, educational
elitism, and technocracy, is one
manifestation of a common problem: the
ability of people to capitulate their selfintegrity in response to power plays instigated by undemocratic agencies.
You, least of anyone, are responsible for
the spiritual torpor on this campus, and no
one in their right mind would expect your
presence to provide an instant cure. But the
same sexism that has kept you off campus
has, along with other forms of
dehumanization, caused great damage to all
aspects of the environment.
You cannot be held accountable for solving
these problems, but your arrival is a sign
that they may finally be confronted with the
full dimension of human capability that they
require.
Welcome.

development ever to take place here, and to
encourage you to join together and actively
implement the necessary environmental
changes that would be impossible without
you.
The predominant spirit motivating this
community becomes apparent in the form of
its architecture. Phallic Gilman Hall, with
its implicit assertions of power and
opulence, rules the setting. Hidden from
sight, and underground, in the passages of
the vagina-like Milton S. Eisenhower
Library, the aspirants pursue these values.
The degree of submissiveness complements the level of aspiration; the
exaggeration of the goals equals the depth to
which we de-elevate in order to attain them.
Hopkins, a fitting reflection of the dreary
Baltimore environment, when as a fine
university, it could generate a vibrant
alternative — is dominated by the
puritanism of its goals, and by the ease with
which it accedes to the prevalent power
structures outside the University.
It is the same capitalism to which so many
members of this community capitulate
personally, and which the University as a
whole fosters, that motivates the American
economy to repress the potential of most of
its citizens, and notably its women.
Waste of Potential
The same waste of potential is manifested
in the fact that the 2000 undergraduate
males, during the most potent years of
youth, experience the possibility of monastic
sexual repression, or of coming to regard
women as weekend plastic Jesuses, simply
because they elected this academic community.
Sexism, and the repressions which it encourages, perhaps plays a part in the other
instances of waste conspicuous at Hopkins:
* the poverty, in the formal curriculum, of
offerings in the Humanities, and especially
in the Social Sciences;
* the absence both of instruction and activity in the performing arts (Writing
Seminars is the happy exception);
* the inability of any sustained political
movement to realize its ends, whether
finally to abolish the Applied Physics
Laboratory and ROTC, or to convince the
community that their presence is justified;
* the failure of the University to actively
extend its educational offices to blacks and

underpriveleged whites who, with the aid of
Upward Bound and transitional year
programs, would be able to appreciate the
full range of resources at Hopkins (and at
Hopkins alone in this region);
* and, the less concrete but nonetheless
significant sense that because the campus is
so decentralized, and because function so
much supercedes person in the prevailing
values, community is impossible.
Admirable Aspect
It is not the most debasing, but the most
admirable aspect of femaleness that can
inspire a richer cultural awareness in the
Hopkins community, increased sensitivity to
the political implications of the university,
ana tne desire of its members to live
together as brothers and sisters.
Your physical presence alone has an intangible, but formidable effect in
humanizing the atmosphere. More definite
changes will require concerted political and
cultural activity, among yourselves, and
together with the groups that have already
formed in order to effect necessary reforms.
Although it caters to the scions of the
upper classes, in its political, social, and
psycho-sexual dimensions, Hopkins remains
an underpriveleged area.
The wholehearted pursuit of any of the
activities that at more normal campuses
enrich the tone of living--music, theater,
dance, helping in the community at large-takes on, in the stultifying atmosphere that
has evolved here, near-revolutionary consequence.
Vestiges of Sexism
It is likely that you will experience, in
formal and spontaneous behaviors, vestiges
of the sexism that has prevailed in this
University for so many years.
But sexism, like militarism, educational
elitism, and technocracy, is one
manifestation of a common problem: the
ability of people to capitulate their selfintegrity in response to power plays instigated by undemocratic agencies.
You, least of anyone, are responsible for
the spiritual torpor on this campus, and no
one in their right mind would expect your
presence to provide an instant cure. But the
same sexism that has kept you off campus
has, along with other forms of
dehumanization, caused great damage to all
aspects of the environment.
You cannot be held accountable for solving
these problems, but your arrival is a sign
that they may finally be confronted with the
full dimension of human capability that they
require.
Welcome.

YAF-10, a four day celebration to commemorate
the tenth anniversary of Young Americans for
Freedom began Wednesday at the University of
Hartford.

Buckley, Jr., ex member of the Yale debating

'Brass' Feet
Don't be surprised if the fellow next to you on the
Greyhound has a few stars on his soldier. In a fit of
mild paranoia, the Army, Navy and Air Force have
urged their top brass to keep their feet on the
ground after the latest rash of hijackings.
The directive to avoid non-military flights also
went out to enlisted men with knowledge of
classified information.
The Navy and Marines even told their men what
to do if they were forced to fly. This includes the
wearing of civilian clothes and carrying a regular
driver's liscense, so as not to call attention to their
military status.
The directive also told the sailors to keep
classified documents in sealed envelopes,
seemingly under the assumption that hijackers
know they're not supposed to read other peoples
mail.

Keep 'em Out
Robert W. Byrd, the Senate's third ranking
Democratic member said Wednesday that the
nation's colleges and universities should purge
radical professors and students, and then adopt
polcies to keep them out.
In a statement to the President's Commission on
Campus Unrest, Byrd said it is time college administrators "return to a policy of making our

institutions of higher learning once again reprpresentative of Mainstream America."
"It is high time that professors who distort the
perspective of young minds, who advocate the
overthrow of our system of government, who
corrupt and pervert the educational process be
purged from our educational institutions," the West
Virginia gentlemen warned.

contributing to the disorder in our institutions is the
presence in those institutions of many young people
who have absolutely no business being there," Byrd
concluded.

South Vietnamese Vice-President Nguyen Cao KY
is reconsidering his scheduled trip to the United
States next month, a government spokesman said
Tuesday.

preacher in the worst Billy Sunday tradition.

South Vietnamese Ambassador to Washington, had

Dealers Drive
The United States Customs officers seized drugs
worth more than $20 million and made 1,361 arrests
during a stepped up drive against narcotics
smugglers from June 1 to August 22.
No precise figures were available for the
corresponding period last year, but a spokesman
said seizures and arrests are up about 20 percent
over the same period last year.
The commissioner of customs, Myles I. Ambrose, said, "We have a customs service that is
breaking all previous records with increasing
seizures and arrests of narcotics smugglers."
He noted that the customs service, with force of a
little more than 10,000 agents was responsible for
clearing more than 250 million travelers a year.

Next Time....
Defense Secretary Melvin Laird has directed the
armed forces to plan to meet future emergencies
like Vietnam by calling up the reserve forces rather
than relying on draftees.
Mr. Laird issued a memorandum instructing the
services to provide in future budgets modern
weapons and equipment to increase the readiness
of National Guard and Reserve forces. The memo.
issued on August 21, was made public earlier this
week.

expand the army from within, forming units with
small numbers of career soldiers and lots of
draftees.

The Boys in Blue in Buffalo, New York have
announced that hence forth they will arrest all
street vendors of the Black Panther newspaper
under a 1902 state criminal anarchy statute now
under review by the United States Supreme Court.
National officials of the Black Panther Party
said, however, that they intend to continue their
paper's activities pending a review of the statute by
the Supreme Court later this fall.
An official of the Buffalo police department said,
"We have been seeking a statute to arrest them
under for some time now. From now on when
(patrolmen) see them selling these papers, they'll
arrest them on the spot."
A New York Panther official said the group was
"confident that the criminal anarchy law will be
overturned by the Supreme Court."

The 1970-71 academic year could provide
the Homewood campus with a breath of
fresh air after several years of stagnation.
Last spring, Dr. George S. Benton, the
former chairman of the Department of
Earth and Planetary Sciences, was selected
as the principle administrator (the Dean of
Arts and Sciences) of Homewood.
His selection came in the midst of student
turmoil over the University's involvement in
war- related research and the hotly-debated
and as yet unresolved question of governance of the University.
The two problems are related to a third,
more basic issue--the gulf that has occurred
between the students and the administrators.
The story is often told over coffee or a
friendly beer of the time of Dr. Eisenhower
(Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, JHU President
1956-66) and of Dean G. Wilson Shaffer and
Student Affairs Director Dr. W. Kelso
Morrill.
Dr. Morrill, an avid lacrosse fan and
former coach and the nemisis and friend of
decades of Hopkins undergrads, died in 1967.
Dr. Eisenhower and Dr. Shaffer have
retired.
The story relates that in those days the
undergraduates were treated as people.
Each of the three key administrators could
associate the names with the faces of over 90
percent of the students.
The personal relationships formed with
these men made JHU a better place for those
students who wanted to study and enjoy their
college days.
It Was no coincidence that the three administrators made every effort to be with the

students especially in athletic endeavors.
Each year over 300 undergrads participate
in intercollegiate athletics, over 400 play on
intramural teams, over 500 use the gymnasium frequently and most of the rest
spectate at football, lacrosse or soccer
contests.
The Eisenhower-Shaffer-Morrill administration knew those students and
learned to like most of them. The reverse
was also true--the students liked the men
who were to them the embodiment of
Hopkins.
Confrontation politics with its pettiness,
fear and hatreds were impossible in such an
atmosphere.
Following the Eisenhower era at JHU, the
Director of Student Affairs was relegated to
the position of a powerless buffer between an
athletic department with a large number of
needs and controversies and the decisionmakers who chose to remain aloof from the
students and their interests.
Dean Benton could change all of that now.
The athletic director should report directly
to the Dean with the almost daily conflicts
and problems that arise when athletic
programs are run with too little money.
Questions of policy should be decided by the
Dean who is the person responsible for the
allocation or withholding of budget funds.
But more important than all of the administrative changes, the Dean should learn
the names and faces of the majority of the
students and require that his subordinates do
the same.
The Dean might find that he even likes
most of us.

Boys in Blue
The Boys in Blue in Buffalo, New York have
announced that hence forth they will arrest all
street vendors of the Black Panther newspaper
under a 1902 state criminal anarchy statute now
under review by the United States Supreme Court.
National officials of the Black Panther Party
said, however, that they intend to continue their
paper's activities pending a review of the statute by
the Supreme Court later this fall.
An official of the Buffalo police department said,
"We have been seeking a statute to arrest them
under for some time now. From now on when
(patrolmen) see them selling these papers, they'll
arrest them on the spot."
A New York Panther official said the group was
"confident that the criminal anarchy law will be
overturned by the Supreme Court."
